user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_get_timeout64s:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN int64_t
MHD_get_timeout64s (struct MHD_Daemon *daemon)
{
  uint64_t utimeout;
  if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &utimeout))
    return -1;
  if (INT64_MAX < utimeout)
    return INT64_MAX;

  return (int64_t) utimeout;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (MHD_NO == MHD_get_timeout64 (daemon, &utimeout))
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The fragment calls MHD_get_timeout64, not MHD_get_timeout64s itself. There is no direct recursion. A violation would occur only if MHD_get_timeout64 (or another function in the call chain) called MHD_get_timeout64s, producing an indirect cycle (for example: MHD_get_timeout64s -> MHD_get_timeout64 -> MHD_get_timeout64s).
